Award.AwardTitle: XPS: FULL: DSD: Asynchronous PDE Algorithms for Turbulent Flows at Exascale

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Future exascale computing systems will be available to study important,
compute-intensive applications such as multi-physics multi-scale natural
phenomena and engineering systems typically modeled accurately by partial
differential equations (PDEs).Â  A prime example is turbulence at high Reynolds
numbers, typically found in natural and engineering systems, which comprise an
extremely wide range of spatial and temporal scales and has thus became a Grand
Challenge in scientific computing.

Many challenges exists that must be overcome before exascale systems
can be utilized effectively. These include communication between
processing elements as well as global synchronizations both of which will
likely be a main bottleneck when millions of billions of processing elements
are utilized in a simulation.

In this project, the PIs develop novel exascale numerical schemes for PDEs,
especially those describing turbulent flows, that exploit asynchrony from the mathematical to
the software level. These are based on widely used finite differences, compact differentiation and spectral schemes.
Asynchrony offers better performance but also introduces errors in the solution. The new schemes will
be able to trade-off accuracy and performance in a quantitative and predictable manner.
The approach includes (i) rigorous mathematical studies of stability and
accuracy based on numerical analysis and dynamical systems, which will also
provide a framework for the development of new schemes and quantify its
uncertainty, (ii) development of specific elements in a scalable library for parallel
computing to enable portable implementations on current and future machines,
and (iii) physics based modeling of numerical perturbations in
realistic flows.

The tools, techniques and simulation data in this project
will be integrated in the PIs' educational efforts through graduate mentoring, undergraduate
research and as material for courses in high-performance computing, fluid dynamics and dynamical systems
taught by the PIs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this part of the project was to devise asynchony tolerant computational approaches based upon phyics considerations rather than modify the numerical scheme. This approach is called the  proxy equation method. In this approach, the PDE being solved numerically is not the original PDE obtained from physics, but a modified equation such that when we solve numerically without enforcing synchronization (i.e. asynchronously) the numerical solution (which contain errors) is indeed the solution to the original PDE. In other words, the equation is pre-corrected for the possibility of asynchrony. When the computations are synchornous, the correction term will vanish, leading to the original equation. 

The main challenge with the proxy-equation approach is that the `correction' term must be determined from the underlying physics. The fundamental finding here was the introduction of "effective" properties in the governing PDE, that is to say, the coefficients associated with physical processes like diffusion or convection, need to be modified to lead to correct results. This requires understanding the effect of delays in the physics of the problem, in particular the processes associate with the different terms present in typical governing equation for fluid mechanics. First efforts included parabolic and hyperbolic effects in a convection-diffusion equation. Subsequent efforts were focused on elliptical equation as it allows asynchronous schemes to be developed on a broader class of physical phenomena. The proof of concept was first established in one (physical) dimensional system and then extended to multiple dimesions. Theproperties of the AT error due to the non-linear process were clearly established.

Our theoretical work on proxy equations shows that extensions to more general PDEs is possible though it requires a careful analysis of modified transport properties. The publications are included in the reference list.
